description: From Late Latin theurgia, from Ancient Greek θεουργία (theourgía, “sorcery”), from θεός (theós, “god”) + ἔργον (érgon, “work”).

entries.meaning: A form of magic designed to allow for worship or conjuration of, or communication with spirits or deities.
examples: And from this he concludes that theurgy is a craft which accomplishes not only good but evil among gods and men; and that the gods also have passions, and are perturbed and agitated by the emotions which Apuleius attributed to demons and men, but from which he preserved the gods by that sublimity of residence, which, in common with Plato, he accorded to them.

entries.meaning: A supernatural intervention in human affairs.
